div.p: THE GRAND DESIGNE: OR A Di≈øcovery of that forme of Slavery, entended, and in part brought upon the free People of England; by a powerfull Party in the Parliament: And L. G. Crumwell, Commi≈ø≈øary Gen. Ireton, and others of that facton in the Army; tending to the utter ruine, and en≈ølaving of the whole Nation.
With the true grounds of the Kings removall to the I≈øle of WIGHT.
ALSO The pretended de≈øigne of Levelling refuted, and cleared from tho≈øe fal≈øe a≈øper≈øions lately, ca≈øt upon the Authors and Promoters of the Peoples Agreement.
Written by SIR RAHNIHO, not an invective, but moderate and impartiall ob≈øerver of the tran≈øactions of the Parliament and Army.
Printed in the la≈øt yeare of Englands Slavery, 1647.

div.head: The Grand De≈øigne, OR A di≈øcovery of that forme of ≈ølavery entended, and in part brought upon the free People of England.
div.p: IN all Ages publique pretences have been made u≈øe of, for the advantaging and ≈øecuring of particular intere≈øts: Not to trace the foot-≈øteps of our Ance≈øtors, I ≈øhall come a little nearer, and bring to memory only the actings of a great party in our pre≈øent Parliament, and ≈øome, yea mo≈øt members in power in the Army, for the proving my A≈ø≈øertion.

And now O ye free Commons of England, remember, at the beginning of this Parliament, what publique pretences were made u≈øe of to unite your affections in the management of their then de≈øigned undertakings? Was there any vi≈øible ≈øuffrage, or indeed ≈øuppo≈øed grievance, depending as a con≈øequent upon the King, and his Parties deportment, that was not laid down, and de-painted in the mo≈øt lively colours; to the end that the actors and contrivers might appeare odious; and the di≈øcoverers, and then oppo≈øers, famous; per≈øons de≈øerving both the love and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of that People, which they ≈øeemingly pretended to deliver from ≈øuch their then declared pre≈ø≈øures and grievances,

At the beginning of this Parliament the whole Repre≈øentative declared again≈øt tho≈øe illegall practi≈øes of the King and his Councell, touching Pattens, Monopolies, illegall Taxes, as Ship-money, and the like, to the end they might the better catch the affections of the People, that groaned under tho≈øe un≈øupportable burthens: But it may be remembred, that after tho≈øe Declarations had netled the Royall party therein concerned; and that ≈øelf-intere≈øt began to run a conte≈øt with publique concernments; how ≈øoon (although before we had a full Parliament declaring) had we an
empty Hou≈øe owning or vindicating the ju≈øtice of tho≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ which they had before declared to be legall, and pro≈øecuting the contrivers and abetters of tho≈øe things which were (as they had declared) illegal, nay rather how ≈øoon had we a great party (≈øwaid by honour and intere≈øt) that (contrary to their own Declarations) did joyne in the maintenance of tho≈øe things, which they had before ≈øo egerly declared again≈øt; viz. the now Lord Hop ‚Ä¢ on, the Lord Capell, Sir Edward Deering, and many others of the Repre≈øentative or Parliament: Which acting and di≈ø≈øenting of theirs, how de≈øtructive it proved to the Kingdome ≈øince, I leave to all wi≈øe men to judge; but to proceed:

After many per≈øons had declined, and deviated from their fir≈øt principles (whereby a bloudy War was occa≈øioned) a ≈øecond party remaining in power, and plau≈øibly pretending the publike ≈øafety (having by pretences of freedome beguiled the Natition to a belief) took upon them (in≈øtead of executing ju≈øtice and judgement without partiality, and imploying the Law, in a way of ≈øafety and pre≈øervation) to oppre≈ø≈øe the oppre≈ø≈øed, and pervert ju≈øtice, to exerci≈øe power, more then rea≈øon, and to make Law ≈øubject to their own inordinate wills; ≈øtraining their priviledges beyond their due limmits, making them altogether unlimmited: which being ob≈øerved and di≈øcovered by ≈øome great men in the Army (who pretended) as in the field) ≈øo in all places) to endeavour the redemption of the Kingdome from ≈ølavery and oppre≈ø≈øion) a de≈øigne was carried on in the Army, and engagements pa≈ø≈øed thereupon, without, yea, again≈øt the Parliamnts liking; in as much as the Parliament had not (by rea≈øon of a malignant party prevalent therein) done tho≈øe things which they had formerly ≈øworn to performe, & were in con≈øcience bound to do, in the di≈øcharge of their tru≈øt to them by the free Commons commited, and for as much as there was a de≈øign to engage the Kingdome in another war, & en≈ølave the People of England under an Arbitrary power; carryed on by Mr. Hollis, Sir Philip Stapleton, and others, as was ≈øuppo≈øed, and as indeed afterwards did manife≈øtly appear: The Army and Councell thereof did agree, and enter into an engagement, (again≈øt the Parliaments liking)
to endeavour and employ all their force to breake and prevent that de≈øign of rai≈øing another Army, and to defend, maintaine, and vindicate the liberties, and Native Birth-rights of all the free Commons of England, again≈øt all the endeavours, or oppo≈øition that could he made again≈øt it. In pur≈øuance whereof, it was by ≈øome per≈øons at L. Gen. Crumwels, he him≈øelfe being pre≈øent, upon monday at night before Whit≈øunday, 1647. re≈øolved, that for a≈ømuch as it was probable that the ≈øaid Hollis and his Party had a determination privately to remove the King to ≈øome place of ≈øtrength, or el≈øe to ≈øet him in the head of another Army; That therefore Cornet George Joyce, ≈øhould with as much ≈øpeed and ≈øecrecy as might be, repaire to Oxford, to give in≈øtructions for the ≈øecuring the Garri≈øon, Magazine and Traine, therein, from the ≈øaid Party then endeavouring to get the ≈øame, and then forthwith to gather ≈øuch a Party of Hor≈øe as he could conveniently get to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and either ≈øecure the per≈øon of the King from being removed by any other, or if occa≈øion were, to remove him to ≈øome place of better ≈øecurity, for the prevention of the de≈øign of the afore≈øaid pretended traiterous Party: Which was accordingly done, both with the knowledge and approbation of L. G. Crumwell, although he afterward (like a ≈øubtle Fox) would not be plea≈øed to take notice of it.

This being done, and the two Polititians, Crumwell and Ireton, finding them≈øelves compleatly ≈øeated in the affections of the ≈øoldiery, having caught them by their plau≈øible pretences of Liberty, Freedome. Indempnity, ≈øecurity, and the like; and being ≈øure likewi≈øe (by rea≈øon of their many Creatures in the Army, which they had advanced to places of promotion, and brought into the Councell) being ≈øure I ≈øay, to carry any thing that they ≈øhould propound, though they might meet with ≈øome oppo≈øers; they ca≈øt about fir≈øt how to un-hor≈øe that Faction that oppo≈øed them; which by a charge of Trea≈øon, and other mi≈ødemeanours (which they never yet had lei≈øure to prove, nor ever will) they in a ≈øhort time accompli≈øhed; which being done they made an e≈ø≈øay to do ≈øomething which ≈øeemed to tend to the e≈øtabli≈øhment of ju≈øtice, ≈øecuring the freedomes of the People, and ea≈øing of
the burthens of the Kingdome (that they might the better catch the affections of the People) which when they found to be ab≈øtructed, and that the ≈øame party and their adherents were ≈øtill prevalent in the Hou≈øe,, and did vote again≈øt their proceedings, and by ≈øecret complotments did bring a tumult upon the Hou≈øe, forcing all members that were not of that party to ab≈øent them≈øelves, e≈øpecially the Speakers, who with many other members came to the Army for ≈øecurity; which members ≈øitting and a≈ø≈øuming a parliamentary power during the Speakers ab≈øence, they declared to be illegall, and thereupon entred into a farther engagement at Houn≈ølo-heath, to march up to London, to purge the Hou≈øe of tho≈øe u≈øurpers of the Parliamentary Power, and to ≈øetle the free Parliament with honour and ≈øafety.

In order whereunto the Army marched up to London, and being in a capacity to performe, what they had undertaken, and declared ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, & conducing to the peace of the Kingdom (by the ≈øubtill Sophi≈øtry of Crumwell and Ireton) the Generall was advi≈øed to leave it unto the Hou≈øe to purge it ≈øelfe, which was accordingly done, and what the effect hath been ≈øince; and how well the Hou≈øe hath been purged, I leave to all wi≈øe men to Judge; they all, or mo≈øt of them ≈øtill remaining therein, and they ≈øince owned and declared a true Parliament.

But by the way you may take notice, that as a gratification the Hou≈øe made the Generall High Con≈øtable of the Tower, and I am ≈øure the L. Generall lo≈øt nothing by that, for he had an old ≈øervant or two to gratify, which he did ≈øuddenly after with places both of profit and concernment; be≈øides, another Creature of his, Col. Hamond was pre≈øently advanced to be Governour of the I≈øle of Wight.

But to proceed, Having now got almo≈øt what they aimed at (to wit) The Per≈øon of the King; a con≈øiderable party in the Parliament; the Militia of the City; and the name of ≈øaving the Kingdome; they then begin to ca≈øt about how, to keep what they haye got, and that they find to be done but by two waies: the fir≈øt, by clo≈øing with the Parliament, in making ≈øuch Propo≈øitions as may plea≈øe the King, and thereby linke them≈øelves ≈øo
to the Kings intere≈øt and power, that they may be thereby ≈øecured from the ju≈øt Taxes of the People which they have ≈øo oppre≈ø≈øed and betrayed; or el≈øe by bringing the Army to the obedience of the Parliament, that by their power, the Parliament might be ≈øtrengthened and enabled to hold both King and Kingdome to hard meate, and at la≈øt if the King would not a≈ø≈øent to what they declare to be fit and requi≈øite, then to depo≈øe him, and take the power into their own hands, and if the Kingdome did not recent or reli≈øh the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, then by the power of the Army to quell and curb them: In order whereunto they ≈øent Propo≈øitions to the King, which being not a≈ø≈øented unto by him, it was put to the que≈øtion, whether they ≈øhould make any more addre≈ø≈øes; which argues that they had a good mind to throw off the King, if they could any way keep their power, and ≈øecure them≈øelves without him: But Ireton declares that he could not promi≈øe the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Army in any ≈øuch matter; his Father in lawes pul≈øes now beating a Lord-like pace, having a little before ki≈ø≈øed the Kings hand, and therefore ≈øince they are not likely to ≈øecure their power without him, they will by him; and to that end the Army mu≈øt be taught a new le≈ø≈øon, and whereas before, freedome, ≈øecurity, the purging of the Hou≈øe, a period ≈øet to the Parliament, and the like, was the only theame; now only ≈øecurity for Arreares, a little pay, &c. mu≈øt be all that the Army de≈øires, and to what end think you, but that they might appear ≈øeekers of them≈øelves, and ≈øo by degrees be lo≈øt in the affections of the People; thus have they in a full careere po≈øted from the Saving, to the En≈ølaving the Kingdome: But by the way they met with a rub, for notwith≈øtanding that, they thought they had made all ≈øure, yet ≈øo it plea≈øed God to order and di≈øpo≈øe things, that their de≈øigne was made manife≈øt, and ≈øome men of upright hearts, were carried out in the ≈øeeking of ju≈øtice, and preventing the en≈ølaving of the Nation, and in order thereunto, did ≈øeverall times, not only oppo≈øe all their en≈ølaving practices, but al≈øo offer unto them in open Councel, ≈øome foundations of common freedome, ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to be in≈øi≈øted on, for the re-e≈øtating of the free Commoners of England in
their antient birth-rights; which they, the ≈øaid De≈øigners, (to wit) Crumwell and Ireton; and the re≈øt of that rayalized Faction could by no meanes relli≈øh; neither would their high aimes ever admit them to debate the ju≈øtne≈ø≈øe thereof; it being altogether cro≈ø≈øe to the Pias of their Ambition: But contrarily they rayled and reviled again≈øt tho≈øe, which either propounded or owned any ≈øuch matter, branding them with the name of dividers of the Army, factious per≈øons, and the like: And being fearefull that after all their labour they ≈øhould now be fru≈øtrated of their expectations, and by ≈øome under-hand dealing be deprived of the darling of their hopes, the King, there mu≈øt be a pretended de≈øigne again≈øt the Kings per≈øon, di≈øcovered by L. G. Crumwell to his Cozen Whaley, and immediately after, (the Guards being fir≈øt doubled) there mu≈øt be a pretended e≈øcape of the King to avoid that pretended danger; but by the way remember, the King affirmes he had withdrawn his promi≈øe made to Col. Whaley, long before this pretended di≈øcovery, which was in order to his departure at that time determined without que≈øtion, and the other but a pretence made u≈øe of to colour the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

It may be remembred that the≈øe manner of pretences are no new things; for when the King fir≈øt di≈øcerted the Parliament, the pretence was Tumults, and the danger of his Per≈øon; and if you would know what tho≈øe tumults were, they were no other but the approaches of his oppre≈ø≈øed Subjects, with cryes for ju≈øtice, which he unju≈øtly denyed both his Parliament and People which becau≈øe he would not grant, he ab≈øented him≈øelfe, and made the danger of his Per≈øon by tho≈øe tumults as he called them, the ground of his departure; although it be notoriou≈øly apparent, that he was then privately providing to make warre with his Parliament and People, and in order thereunto, was ≈øending the jewels of the Crown to purcha≈øe Armes in Holland for the managing of the de≈øign afore≈øaid.

Which acting and pretences then being compared with his pre≈øent acting in relation to his departure from Hampton Court, and the now pretended cau≈øe thereof, will plainly appeare to be of the ≈øame ≈øtamp with the former; and in deed no other but a
de≈øign, not only to make odious, but al≈øo if advantage be offered, to cut off, and de≈øtroy all the godly per≈øons in the Kingdome, that ≈øhall but in the lea≈øt endeavour to oppo≈øe the exerci≈øe of his, and their Prerogative en≈ølaving tirannicall practi≈øes, in the ≈øecuring of the Peoples ju≈øt Rights and Freedomes.

But if you ≈øhall con≈øider further, whether mu≈øt the King fly, or rather be carried, to avoid the pretended danger, but to Hammond at the I≈øle of Wight, one of Crumwels own creatures, there to remain, untill ≈øuch time as Propo≈øitions can be made ready ≈øutable to the Kings de≈øire, and an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for the Parliaments indempnity; and then O you poore betrayed Commons, where will you obtain ju≈øtice or ≈øecurity, when your Tru≈øtees that pretended to deliver you, ≈øhall have thus to advance them≈øelves, betraied you.

And now if you ≈øhall de≈øire a rea≈øon why the≈øe men ≈øhould now at la≈øt derogate from their former pretended Principles; and ≈øhould not now, as heretofore, endeavour to ≈øecure the Peoples ju≈øt freedomes.
I an≈øwer; the Parliament, (or at lea≈øt a great part of them) are now brought to ≈øuch an exigency, that they cannot act otherwi≈øe with ≈øecurity to them≈øelves.

It is ea≈øie to demon≈øtrate unto the world, that many of their actions have not, neither can they be warranted by Law, e≈øpecially their Arbitrary and illegall ≈øommoning, and committing per≈øons (contrary to Law) which all knowing men are re≈øolved for the future to prote≈øt again≈øt, and oppo≈øe, maugre the power of all that ≈øhall endeavour the execution or ju≈øtification of tho≈øe unju≈øt and tyrannicall practi≈øes:) And likewi≈øe, that by their continued, and redoubled oppre≈ø≈øions brought upon the Kingdome, they have not only lo≈øt the friend≈øhip of the People, but in a great mea≈øure purcha≈øed their enmity; ≈øo that now their condition is ≈øuch, that either they mu≈øt clo≈øe with the King, who≈øe intere≈øt in the People is now greater then theirs, having got what they have lo≈øt) that ≈øo,
what they cannot promi≈øe them≈øelves by their own power, they can a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves by his, (who without doubt hath ≈øo much policy as to promi≈øe both ≈øecurity & advancement to a part, that he may the ea≈øilyer get into a capacity of en≈ølaving the whole.

To be a little plainer; It cannot be immagined improbable, that the Parliament having lo≈øt the love of the People, doubting the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Army, and wanting means (though without que≈øtion they have wills) to enable them to throw off the King, and by force to maintain their actions legall; I ≈øay, can it by any that have ≈øence or rea≈øon be imagined, that they will not to ≈øecure them≈øelves from the taxes of the People, the la≈øh of the Law, and Levelling, as they tearme it; that is, from being made (as all other Subjects) accountable to the Law, and People for all their actions) take any advantage or oportunity? And what better advantage can they have, then to joyn with the King? that by a≈ø≈øenting unto his de≈øires, they may engratiate them≈øelves into his favour, and wrapping them≈øelves up in his Mantle of tirannicall Royalty, and Protection, in their own honour & ≈øecurity, leave all the free Commons of England, (by them animated, authorized, nay enforced to fight again≈øt, and ≈øubdue him) expo≈øed to the exa≈øperated rage of a conquered King, and incen≈øed Party, who will not faile, being once in power, to exalt them≈øelves in, and by the ruine of their oppo≈øers; and like legitimate Imps of their Tyrant-exalter, Lord it over the Kingdome.

And if you ≈øhall ask, wherein Crumwell, Ireton, and the re≈øt of that Faction, are concerned in the Parliaments actions; I An≈øwer, they are Parliament men, and ≈øo bound up in the Parliaments actings; and indeed ≈øo involved in the Parliaments intere≈øt, (joyned to their own ends) that I can thinke it no other then a difficult matter, for them to deny them≈øelves in this Particular; Honour and profit being very potent allurements in the≈øe our ≈øelf-loving dayes.

It is ob≈øervable that the≈øe two Polititians Crumwell, and Ireton, at fir≈øt were eager again≈øt all per≈øons that vi≈øibly oppo≈øed them in the Parliament, but would never yeeld to the purging of the Hou≈øe,, only they would never be quiet till they had got out all tho≈øe that any way oppo≈øed them; witnes the late charge again≈øt the eleven Members, where (although Crumwel him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øed at Colbrooke, that he had nothing again≈øt Sir John Mainard; yet he mu≈øt be put in among the re≈øt, and only becau≈øe he was a bu≈øie man again≈øt him and his faction: Having removed them he remaines ≈øatisfyed, untill he finds another party of Pellamites which endeavour to throw him out of the Sadle; and then he comes in with (I am per≈øwaded) a hearty ≈øorrow, confe≈ø≈øing, and praying God to forgive him, becau≈øe he had hindered the purging of the Hou≈øe: And why is the Lievtenant Generall ≈øo penitent thinke you? but only becau≈øe he feared they would be ≈øome hinderance to his high aimes.

And here I ≈øhall in≈øert this Quere, Whether, con≈øidering that there are two Parties acting for particular intere≈øt, and each of them endeavouring to bring in the King, for the advancement of their own party, whether, I ≈øay, it be not probable that the King was removed by de≈øign, and enduced by engagement, to alter his former re≈øolution of not being removed; le≈øt the Pellamites ≈øhould have ≈øerved Crumwell at Hampton, as he ≈øerved them at Holdenby? For my part if it were not ≈øo, it is to me a Ridle, which none I believe can unfold but hone≈øt Oliver,
But to proceed, It may be demanded, ≈øeing that Crumwell is ≈øo active for his own parties intere≈øt, why the other party being as yet mo≈øt powerfull in the Hou≈øe have not outed him of his power?

I an≈øwer, could they but bring the King in upon their own intere≈øt, and thereby ≈øecure them≈øelves in the attempt; I am confident they would tread him and his adherents low enough: and that the Lievtenant General knowes well; otherwi≈øe
Hammond had never been Lord Chamberlaine; nor the King removed to the I≈øle of Wight; though I believe he never dreamt of the con≈øequences that have happened, and and are like to ≈øucceed therupon; that by the way; but to proceed, the King being gone, the City di≈øta≈øting them, or indeed over-awed, not daring by rea≈øon of their own divi≈øions, to appeare with, or for them; the Country wearied, and rather enclinable to endeavour the di≈ø≈øolution of their power, then any way to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in the maintenance or ≈øupport thereof; and which is wor≈øt of all, the Army, (which ≈øhould by their power make their commands authentique) utterly rejecting their authority, and rendering them a trayterous Party, and per≈øons endeavouring the de≈øtruction of the ju≈øt rights and freedomes of the People; the≈øe things being duely con≈øidered, you may plainly ≈øee, that it is more for feare, then favour, that they clo≈øe with him, he being both politicke and powerfull, by rea≈øon of his adherents in the Hou≈øe, and creatures in the Army, in re≈øpect of which al≈øo they could not make u≈øe of a fitter in≈øtrument, to draw the Army to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, if it might be; for the Father and the Sonne, with the re≈øt of their Family, from generation to generation, have the command of halfe the Army, all which having received their promotion and Principle from Crumwell, and looking ≈øtill to ri≈øe with him, will not move a foot beyond his in≈øtruction, nor as neare as they can, fall ≈øhort of it; and as the King is his Idoll, ≈øo he is theirs, hanging altogether in the executing what their own honour and intere≈øt dictates unto them.

It is a commendable thing in the Lievetenant Generall to advance his kindred, and ≈øervants, ≈øo it be done by good wayes, and for ju≈øt ends; not to advance lawle≈ø≈øe ambition, & ≈øtrengthen irregular attempts, if ≈øo; he may chance in the mid≈øt of his Golden hopes meet with Buckinghams Fate, or Straffords doome, and in ≈øtead of honour inherit infamy.

Thus having in ≈øome mea≈øure di≈øcovered unto you their actings in relation to the betraying the free People of England to an Arbitrary power, contrary to the Protestations of Parliament, and engagements of the Army.

I will now, in oppo≈øition to this their practice, lay you down the heads of that foundation of freedome prop ‚Ä¢ unded, and by them oppo≈øed, and to the Kingdome rendered odious, under the notion of Parity, Community, Levelling, de≈øtroying Magi≈øtracy, and the like, to the end that you may plainly judge betwixt us and them, and ≈øee who they be that indeed labour to inve≈øt you with your ju≈øt rights and liberties.

div.head: The Agreement:
div.p: 1. That the People of England being at this day very unequally di≈øtributed by Counties, Cities and Boroughs, for the Election of their Deputies in Parliament, ought to be more indifferrently proportioned according to the number of the Inhabitants.

That is, for as much as by the late co≈øtomes of this Nation, there were but two per≈øons cho≈øen as Repre≈øentatives for each County, and tho≈øe by the con≈øent and approbation of per≈øons of ≈øuch a rancke, quality, and condition, as free-holders, &c. which per≈øons cho≈øen as Repre≈øentatives have commonly been ≈øuch as were in ≈øome mea≈øure linckt in, or related to, the prerogative of the King, either by promotions received or expected; and likewi≈øe for as much as the per≈øons cho≈øing are commonly more ≈øwaid by favour then rea≈øon in their choyce, being Tenants either to the per≈øons cho≈øen, or their friends; which hath been one main rea≈øon that the lo≈øt liberties of the Kingdome have beene from time to time no better vindicated and pre≈øerved; That therefore from henceforth their might be per≈øons cho≈øen for Repre≈øentatives for every County, proportioable
to the number of Inhabitants in each County, and that not by freeholdolders only, but by the voluntary a≈ø≈øent of all men that are not ≈øervants or Beggers, it being pure equity, that as all per≈øons are bound to yeild obedience to the decrees of the Repre≈øentative or Parliament, ≈øo they ≈øhould have a voyce in the electing their Repre≈øentatives, or Members of Parliament.
2. That to prevent the many inconveniences apparently ari≈øing from the long continuance of tho≈øe per≈øons in authority, this pre≈øent Parliament be di≈ø≈øolved, &c.

That is, for as much as the long continuance of the Power of Parliament men proveth very de≈øtructive to the liberty of the People, and occa≈øioneth their falling into parties and factions, and giveth them great countenance in the exerci≈øing of an arbitrary power: that therefore they be continued but for a ≈øhort time, and that during that time they may remain accountable to tho≈øe that cho≈øe and entru≈øted them.

And for that clau≈øe in the agreement, to wit, That in all Lawes made or to be made, every per≈øon may be bound alike, and that no Tenure, Estate, Charter, De≈øigne, birth or place; doe conferre any exemption from the ordinary cour≈øe of legall proceedings whereunto others are ≈øubjected, which they make the ground of a≈øper≈øing the pro≈øecutors thereof with the name of Levellers and pulling down Magi≈øtracy; it is indeed no other but this, That whereas now ≈øeverall per≈øons are by an u≈øurped power exalted above the Law, and protected from due proce≈øs at Law, (viz) Lords as Peers, allhough legally indebted, may not be touched with an arre≈øt, nor be made ≈øubject to the cen≈øure of the Law; whereby they have made little con≈øcience when they have got mens e≈øtates in their hands, to returne the ≈øame, but have ≈øtood upon their Prerogative and thereby been protected, to the utter ruine and undoing of many of the free people of England.

And likewi≈øe whereas not only the per≈øons but habitations
of ≈øuch Per≈øons are made ≈øanctuaries for per≈øons indebted; that the≈øe things might be for the future removed, and both per≈øons and places put under the power of the Law,; and this is the whole ≈øumme of that great de≈øign of Levelling you hear ≈øo much of.

For all other matters I referre you to the Agreement it ≈øelf, which being ≈øeriou≈øly and impartially ≈øcanned, I am confident will give any man not ≈øwaid with intere≈øt or prejudice, ≈øufficient ≈øatisfaction; and I doubt not, (maugre the malice and oppo≈øition of all ≈øorts of men) will ere long appear to be indeed that which ultimately conduceth to the freedome and ≈øecurity bothof the Magi≈øtracy (if ≈øetled in its right orbe) and all other the now oppre≈ø≈øed and almo≈øt en≈ølaved Commons of England.
